image.altText: A sign saying emergency pointing towards a colourful building.

items.synopsis: Tasmanians are being urged seek "alternative healthcare options" to take pressure off the state's two main hospitals. Health unions say the situation is "the worst it's ever been".

title.children: 'People will die': Dire warnings from health unions as Tasmanians urged to stay away from hospitals amid surge

image.altText: Man stands in front of a large drum of cable.

items.synopsis: The Tasmanian government details the $1.7 billion reason for downgrading the Marinus Link electricity interconnector from two to one cables, but opposition parties say many questions about costs remain unanswered.

title.children: Less than a year on, undersea cable project blows out by almost $2b

image.altText: Twenty-year-old Johnson Kokozian wearing a cap looking at the camera and smiling

items.synopsis: NSW Police also confirmed two more people had been charged in relation to the crash.

title.children: Driver accused of killing siblings in Sydney crash has dangerous driving charges upgraded

image.altText: A woman in a grocery isle of fruit and vegetables

items.synopsis: The latest GDP data shows an annual slowdown in the Australian economy because of interest rate hikes.  Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: Economy grows by 2.1 per cent in 12 months, Wall Street falls, Australian dollar tumbles

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Senate has passed a law to allow competition in the transfer of stock ownership. The market operator, the Australian Securities Exchange carries out most clearing and settlement services in Australia. But a failed software overhaul of its trading system saw the federal government open up the market to other players. Here's Assistant Treasurer Stephen Jones: "The legislation which passed through the Senate today will support competition in clearing and settlement services, which are critical to the functioning and stability of financial markets." "It creates a framework for fair, transparent and non‑discriminatory access to market infrastructure for any emerging competitors, allowing them to offer their own clearing and settlement services." The new rules also give the Reserve Bank and the Australian Securities and Investments Commission greater oversight of clearing and settlement providers. The Australian Competition and Consumer Commission will have the power to arbitrate disputes between parties around the price and access to clearing and settlement services.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX to face competition in share settlement and clearing

children.content: The Senate has passed a law to allow competition in the transfer of stock ownership.
The market operator, the Australian Securities Exchange carries out most
clearing and settlement services
in Australia.
But a failed software overhaul of its trading system saw the federal government open up the market to other players.
Here's Assistant Treasurer Stephen Jones:
"The legislation which passed through the Senate today will support competition in clearing and settlement services, which are critical to the functioning and stability of financial markets."
"It creates a framework for fair, transparent and non‑discriminatory access to market infrastructure for any emerging competitors, allowing them to offer their own clearing and settlement services."
The new rules also give the Reserve Bank and the Australian Securities and Investments Commission greater oversight of clearing and settlement providers.
The Australian Competition and Consumer Commission will have the power to arbitrate disputes between parties around the price and access to clearing and settlement services.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Australian share market has fallen deeper into the red in afternoon trade. It's down around three quarters of a percent in the last hour of trade with most sectors lower. Leading the losses are technology, industrials, consumer firms, and telecommunications. Energy stocks are the rare bright spot after oil prices rose overnight as Saudi Arabia and Russia extended production cuts. Qantas shares have increased 1.3 per cent today as new boss Vanessa Hudson takes the reins from Alan Joyce. Packaging firm Orora is taking a hit because of plans to raise $1.35 billion in a discounted share placement to fund its purchase of French glass bottle maker Saverglass. ASX 200 movers: Domain: +2.6% Telix Pharmaceuticals: +2.% HMC Capital: +2.1% Orora: -10.9% Imugene: -5.2% Altium: -4.9%
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Australian market extends its falls

children.content: The Australian share market has fallen deeper into the red in afternoon trade.
It's down around three quarters of a percent in the last hour of trade with most sectors lower.
Leading the losses are technology, industrials, consumer firms, and telecommunications.
Energy
stocks are the rare bright spot after oil prices rose overnight as Saudi Arabia and Russia extended production cuts.
Qantas
shares have increased 1.3 per cent today as new boss Vanessa Hudson takes the reins from Alan Joyce.
Packaging firm
Orora
is taking a hit because of plans to raise $1.35 billion in a discounted share placement to fund its purchase of French glass bottle maker Saverglass.
ASX 200 movers:
Domain: +2.6%
Telix Pharmaceuticals: +2.%
HMC Capital: +2.1%
Orora: -10.9%
Imugene: -5.2%
Altium: -4.9%

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Some other economic data out today. Employment website Seek says job ads fell by 1.8 per cent in August from July, and they are down by nearly one fifth over the year. Applications per job increased by 6.5 per cent in August. That continues the trend we've been seeing for awhile after job ads peaked at record highs last year. More migration and a slowing economy means employers have more workers to choose from. Here's Seek managing director Kendra Banks: “After a slight rise in July, job ads declined 1.8 per cent in August driven by a drop in volumes in New South Wales. “Victoria and the Northern Territory were the only states to buck the trend, with regional job ad volumes in Victoria driving overall job ads up for the state, particularly those in retail & consumer products. "Ads for retail & consumer products roles rose nationally for the second month, as businesses begin preparing for the Christmas season." “Applications per job ad continue to rise, and after six months of growth, levels are now higher than they were in July 2019, demonstrating that competition for jobs is greater than it was pre-COVID." However, demand for labour is still strong with the unemployment near fifty year lows of 3.7 per cent in July. Hospitality and tourism job ads were down by 3.1 per cent in August and they are down by nearly 41 per cent over the year, which suggests new migrants and international students are filling more of these jobs.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Job ads fall in August

children.content: Some other economic data out today.
Employment website Seek says job ads fell by 1.8 per cent in August from July, and they are down by nearly one fifth over the year.
Applications per job increased by 6.5 per cent in August.
That
continues the trend we've been seeing for awhile after job ads peaked at record highs last year.
More migration and a slowing economy means employers have more workers to choose from.

props.alt: Map of Australia showing decline in job ads across states and territories

children.content: Job ads fall
(Seek)
Here's Seek managing director Kendra Banks:
“After a slight rise in July, job ads declined 1.8 per cent in August driven by a drop in volumes in New South Wales.
“Victoria and the Northern Territory were the only states to buck the trend, with regional job ad volumes in Victoria driving overall job ads up for the state, particularly those in retail
consumer products.
"Ads for retail
consumer products roles rose nationally for the second month, as businesses begin preparing for the Christmas season."

“Applications per job ad continue to rise, and after six months of growth, levels are now higher than they were in July 2019, demonstrating that competition for jobs is greater than it was pre-COVID."
However, demand for labour is still strong with the unemployment near fifty year lows of 3.7 per cent in July.

Hospitality and tourism job ads were down by 3.1 per cent in August and they are down by nearly 41 per cent over the year, which suggests new migrants and international students are filling more of these jobs.

items.synopsis: Australia's economy is growing at an annual pace of 2.1 per cent, down from 2.7 per cent at the end of 2022.

title.children: Australia's economy continued to slow in June quarter, households finding it harder to save

image.altText: Four Corners obtained footage showing the tear gassing of boys being held in isolation at the Don Dale Youth Detention Centre in Darwin, in August 201

image.altText: A mother and father holding their young daughter between them, smiling. They are standing on an apartment balcony.

image.altText: Vanessa Hudson, the incoming Qantas CEO, with model plane in foreground showing Flying Kangaroo

image.altText: A man lays in a hospital bed as an elderly woman holds his hand

image.altText: young girl on bus.

image.altText: Two men look at the camera. They are standing on land.

title.children: With his last interest rates decision made, will Philip Lowe move to a private bank?

items.synopsis: Ernie Bot, a generative AI chatbot, is now fully accessible to the public. But how powerful can it be in a realm of heavily censored internet use, and how does this fit into China's vision of becoming the world leader in AI?
